synthesis_conditions.description: Tris-sarcosine calcium chloride exhibits a second-order displacive phase transition near this temperature.
A phase transition is marked by very strong mechanical losses and a large specific heat anomaly.
Dielectric and polarization anomalies are reproducible but much smaller.
A smooth evolution of displacement parameters is seen, with no direct evidence of further phase transitions.
The polarization does not vanish; instead, it increases an additional 10% as temperature lowers.
Substitution can lower the critical temperature to a quantum critical point at 0 K.
Raman data show a strong decrease in intensity of the lowest-frequency modes near 65 cm−1 and increase in their splitting, and the appearance of an intense new mode near 115 cm−1.
A mode near 500 cm−1 splits into a doublet ∼25 cm−1 apart.
